title: Most Expensive Listing in the U.S. Is Bel Air Mansion Asking $225 Million
text:
Casa Encantada won't hit the public market, but is available for $225 million.

Text size

A sprawling 60-room Bel Air, California, estate dubbed Casa Encantada was put up for sale last week for $225 million, eclipsing the price of anything else on the market right now in the U.S.

The Georgian-style spread is “the finest mansion that has ever come on the market,” according to listing agent Jeff Hyland of brokerage Hilton & Hyland.

Pricing the property was easy, he said, despite a lack of homes to turn to for comparison. “We have eight-and-a-half acres in Bel Air and $20 million is the average price per acre,” he said.

Add to that a 40,000-square-foot home that can’t be recreated and “that’s what gives it the valuation,” Mr. Hyland said.

After the first $100 million sale in Los Angeles in 2016, “we opened up the floodgates” for increasingly higher sales, Mr. Hyland said.

There was a recording-breaking $110 million sale of the Malibu home belonging to Hard Rock Cafe co-founder Peter Morton in 2018. Earlier this year, the record was broken once again by the $120 million sale of The Manor, a sprawling estate built for the late TV producer Aaron Spelling.

“Chartwell will beat that,” according to Mr. Hyland, referring to the opulent estate that was made famous as the set of the 1960s TV series "The Beverly Hillbillies.”

Asking $195 million, Chartwell had been Los Angeles’s most expensive home on the market, until this listing. When Chartwell first came on the market in 2018, it had a $245 million price tag.

As might be expected, the home is very private, tucked away behind large gates. Simon Berlyn

Another home that had once been asking as much as $250 million recently found a buyer for around $94 million, the Wall Street Journal reported Thursday, demonstrating that discounts are often necessary to secure a sale for these nine-figure homes.

Mr. Hyland predicts that the sale of Casa Encantada will be the “ultimate record.”

Nestled above the Bel Air Country Club, the property’s history is replete with well-to-do ownership.

The trophy home was built in 1938 for Hilda Weber, the widow of a multimillionaire glass manufacturer. Weber commissioned architect James E. Dolena —famed for his work building lavish Los Angeles homes, including Walt Disney’s Carolwood Estate—for the project.

In 1950, Weber sold Casa Encantada to hotel magnate Conrad Hilton for $225,000, and following Hilton’s death in 1979, it changed hands once more, selling to billionaire businessman David Murdock for $12.4 million, a U.S. record at the time, according to the Los Angeles Times.

The estate was acquired by its current owner, financier Gary Winnick, in 2000 for $94 million, property records show, a figure that was reportedly another nationwide record at the time.

Mr. Winnick, 72—who declined to comment on the listing—and his wife, Karen, brought in architect and designer Peter Marino, who alongside a team of 250 craftsmen, spent more than two years restoring the estate to a “museum-quality,” according to a news release.

There’s an entry hall with 18-foot-high ceilings, a pool house with a professional screening room and formal bar, a tennis court, a basketball court, Koi ponds and a guest house, the release said.

The house will not be hitting the public market.

“It’s not going on the MLS; it doesn’t need to be,” Mr. Hyland said. “Everyone who needs to know about it, will know about it.”

The Los Angeles Times first reported the listing.

This article first appeared on Mansion Global.
description: California’s 60-room Casa Encantada is owned by Gary Winnick
